message.content:
I need to understand the current state of the memory system implementation in the vault at D:\10_pur3v4d3r's-vault.

Please investigate and report on:

1. **Existing .claude/ Directory Structure**
   - What subdirectories exist? (core/, task-logs/, plans/, errors/)
   - What files are in each directory?
   - Do the files follow the documented memory system format?

2. **Smart Connections Configuration**
   - Check if .smart-env/ directory exists with embeddings
   - Look for Smart Connections plugin configuration in .obsidian/plugins/smart-connections/
   - Check if .claude/ directory is excluded from indexing (should NOT be excluded)

3. **MCP Configuration Status**
   - Look for any existing MCP configuration indicators
   - Check for any smart-connections MCP setup references

4. **Memory File Examples**
   - Read 1-2 example files from .claude/ to understand current format
   - Check if they use the query anchor protocol (%%QA:domain:topic%%)
   - Check if they have proper metadata frontmatter

Provide a detailed status report that will help me determine:
- What's already working
- What needs to be configured
- What gaps exist in the current implementation

Focus on READ-ONLY exploration. Do not make any changes.

1â†’# Manage Claude's memory 2â†’ 3â†’> Learn how to manage Claude Code's memory across sessions with different memory locations and best practices. 4â†’ 5â†’Claude Code can remember your preferences across sessions, like style guidelines and common commands in your workflow. 6â†’ 7â†’## Determine memory type 8â†’ 9â†’Claude Code offers four memory locations in a hierarchical structure, each serving a different purpose: 10â†’ 11â†’| Memory Type | Location | Purpose | Use Case Examples | Shared With | 12â†’| -------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------- | 13â†’| **Enterprise policy** | â€¢ macOS: `/Library/Application Support/ClaudeCode/CLAUDE.md`
â€¢ Linux: `/etc/claude-code/CLAUDE.md`
â€¢ Windows: `C:\Program Files\ClaudeCode\CLAUDE.md` | Organization-wide instructions managed by IT/DevOps | Company coding standards, security policies, compliance requirements | All users in organization | 14â†’| **Project memory** | `./CLAUDE.md` or `./.claude/CLAUDE.md` | Team-shared instructions for the project | Project architecture, coding standards, common workflows | Team members via source control | 15â†’| **Project rules** | `./.claude/rules/*.md` | Modular, topic-specific project instructions | Language-specific guidelines, testing conventions, API standards | Team members via source control | 16â†’| **User memory** | `~/.claude/CLAUDE.md` | Personal preferences for all projects | Code styling preferences, personal tooling shortcuts | Just you (all projects) | 17â†’| **Project memory (local)** | `./CLAUDE.local.md` | Personal project-specific preferences | Your sandbox URLs, preferred test data | Just you (current project) | 18â†’ 19â†’All memory files are automatically loaded into Claude Code's context when launched. Files higher in the hierarchy take precedence and are loaded first, providing a foundation that more specific memories build upon. 20â†’ 21â†’ 22â†’ CLAUDE.local.md files are automatically added to .gitignore, making them ideal for private project-specific preferences that shouldn't be checked into version control. 23â†’ 24â†’ 25â†’## CLAUDE.md imports 26â†’ 27â†’CLAUDE.md files can import additional files using `@path/to/import` syntax. The following example imports 3 files: 28â†’ 29â†’``` 30â†’See @README for project overview and @package.json for available npm commands for this project. 31â†’ 32â†’# Additional Instructions 33â†’- git workflow @docs/git-instructions.md 34â†’``` 35â†’ 36â†’Both relative and absolute paths are allowed. In particular, importing files in user's home dir is a convenient way for your team members to provide individual instructions that are not checked into the repository. Imports are an alternative to CLAUDE.local.md that work better across multiple git worktrees. 37â†’ 38â†’``` 39â†’# Individual Preferences 40â†’- @~/.claude/my-project-instructions.md 41â†’``` 42â†’ 43â†’To avoid potential collisions, imports are not evaluated inside markdown code spans and code blocks. 44â†’ 45â†’``` 46â†’This code span will not be treated as an import: `@anthropic-ai/claude-code` 47â†’``` 48â†’ 49â†’Imported files can recursively import additional files, with a max-depth of 5 hops. You can see what memory files are loaded by running `/memory` command. 50â†’ 51â†’## How Claude looks up memories 52â†’ 53â†’Claude Code reads memories recursively: starting in the cwd, Claude Code recurses up to (but not including) the root directory */* and reads any CLAUDE.md or CLAUDE.local.md files it finds. This is especially convenient when working in large repositories where you run Claude Code in *foo/bar/*, and have memories in both *foo/CLAUDE.md* and *foo/bar/CLAUDE.md*. 54â†’ 55â†’Claude will also discover CLAUDE.md nested in subtrees under your current working directory. Instead of loading them at launch, they are only included when Claude reads files in those subtrees. 56â†’ 57â†’## Directly edit memories with `/memory` 58â†’ 59â†’Use the `/memory` slash command during a session to open any memory file in your system editor for more extensive additions or organization. 60â†’ 61â†’## Set up project memory 62â†’ 63â†’Suppose you want to set up a CLAUDE.md file to store important project information, conventions, and frequently used commands. Project memory can be stored in either `./CLAUDE.md` or `./.claude/CLAUDE.md`. 64â†’ 65â†’Bootstrap a CLAUDE.md for your codebase with the following command: 66â†’ 67â†’``` 68â†’> /init 69â†’``` 70â†’ 71â†’ 72â†’ Tips: 73â†’ 74â†’ * Include frequently used commands (build, test, lint) to avoid repeated searches 75â†’ * Document code style preferences and naming conventions 76â†’ * Add important architectural patterns specific to your project 77â†’ * CLAUDE.md memories can be used for both instructions shared with your team and for your individual preferences. 78â†’ 79â†’ 80â†’## Modular rules with `.claude/rules/` 81â†’ 82â†’For larger projects, you can organize instructions into multiple files using the `.claude/rules/` directory. This allows teams to maintain focused, well-organized rule files instead of one large CLAUDE.md. 83â†’ 84â†’### Basic structure 85â†’ 86â†’Place markdown files in your project's `.claude/rules/` directory: 87â†’ 88â†’``` 89â†’your-project/ 90â†’â”œâ”€â”€ .claude/ 91â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ CLAUDE.md # Main project instructions 92â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€ rules/ 93â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ code-style.md # Code style guidelines 94â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ testing.md # Testing conventions 95â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€ security.md # Security requirements 96â†’``` 97â†’ 98â†’All `.md` files in `.claude/rules/` are automatically loaded as project memory, with the same priority as `.claude/CLAUDE.md`. 99â†’ 100â†’### Path-specific rules 101â†’ 102â†’Rules can be scoped to specific files using YAML frontmatter with the `paths` field. These conditional rules only apply when Claude is working with files matching the specified patterns. 103â†’ 104â†’```markdown theme={null} 105â†’--- 106â†’paths: src/api/**/*.ts 107â†’--- 108â†’ 109â†’# API Development Rules 110â†’ 111â†’- All API endpoints must include input validation 112â†’- Use the standard error response format 113â†’- Include OpenAPI documentation comments 114â†’``` 115â†’ 116â†’Rules without a `paths` field are loaded unconditionally and apply to all files. 117â†’ 118â†’### Glob patterns 119â†’ 120â†’The `paths` field supports standard glob patterns: 121â†’ 122â†’| Pattern | Matches | 123â†’| ---------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | 124â†’| `**/*.ts` | All TypeScript files in any directory | 125â†’| `src/**/*` | All files under `src/` directory | 126â†’| `*.md` | Markdown files in the project root | 127â†’| `src/components/*.tsx` | React components in a specific directory | 128â†’ 129â†’You can use braces to match multiple patterns efficiently: 130â†’ 131â†’```markdown theme={null} 132â†’--- 133â†’paths: src/**/*.{ts,tsx} 134â†’--- 135â†’ 136â†’# TypeScript/React Rules 137â†’``` 138â†’ 139â†’This expands to match both `src/**/*.ts` and `src/**/*.tsx`. You can also combine multiple patterns with commas: 140â†’ 141â†’```markdown theme={null} 142â†’--- 143â†’paths: {src,lib}/**/*.ts, tests/**/*.test.ts 144â†’--- 145â†’``` 146â†’ 147â†’### Subdirectories 148â†’ 149â†’Rules can be organized into subdirectories for better structure: 150â†’ 151â†’``` 152â†’.claude/rules/ 153â†’â”œâ”€â”€ frontend/ 154â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ react.md 155â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€ styles.md 156â†’â”œâ”€â”€ backend/ 157â†’â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ api.md 158â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€ database.md 159â†’â””â”€â”€ general.md 160â†’``` 161â†’ 162â†’All `.md` files are discovered recursively. 163â†’ 164â†’### Symlinks 165â†’ 166â†’The `.claude/rules/` directory supports symlinks, allowing you to share common rules across multiple projects: 167â†’ 168â†’```bash theme={null} 169â†’# Symlink a shared rules directory 170â†’ln -s ~/shared-claude-rules .claude/rules/shared 171â†’ 172â†’# Symlink individual rule files 173â†’ln -s ~/company-standards/security.md .claude/rules/security.md 174â†’``` 175â†’ 176â†’Symlinks are resolved and their contents are loaded normally. Circular symlinks are detected and handled gracefully. 177â†’ 178â†’### User-level rules 179â†’ 180â†’You can create personal rules that apply to all your projects in `~/.claude/rules/`: 181â†’ 182â†’``` 183â†’~/.claude/rules/ 184â†’â”œâ”€â”€ preferences.md # Your personal coding preferences 185â†’â””â”€â”€ workflows.md # Your preferred workflows 186â†’``` 187â†’ 188â†’User-level rules are loaded before project rules, giving project rules higher priority. 189â†’ 190â†’ 191â†’ Best practices for `.claude/rules/`: 192â†’ 193â†’ * **Keep rules focused**: Each file should cover one topic (e.g., `testing.md`, `api-design.md`) 194â†’ * **Use descriptive filenames**: The filename should indicate what the rules cover 195â†’ * **Use conditional rules sparingly**: Only add `paths` frontmatter when rules truly apply to specific file types 196â†’ * **Organize with subdirectories**: Group related rules (e.g., `frontend/`, `backend/`) 197â†’ 198â†’ 199â†’## Organization-level memory management 200â†’ 201â†’Enterprise organizations can deploy centrally managed CLAUDE.md files that apply to all users. 202â†’ 203â†’To set up organization-level memory management: 204â†’ 205â†’1. Create the enterprise memory file at the **Enterprise policy** location shown in the [memory types table above](#determine-memory-type). 206â†’ 207â†’2. Deploy via your configuration management system (MDM, Group Policy, Ansible, etc.) to ensure consistent distribution across all developer machines. 208â†’ 209â†’## Memory best practices 210â†’ 211â†’* **Be specific**: "Use 2-space indentation" is better than "Format code properly". 212â†’* **Use structure to organize**: Format each individual memory as a bullet point and group related memories under descriptive markdown headings. 213â†’* **Review periodically**: Update memories as your project evolves to ensure Claude is always using the most up to date information and context. 214â†’ 215â†’ 216â†’--- 217â†’ 218â†’> To find navigation and other pages in this documentation, fetch the llms.txt file at: https://code.claude.com/docs/llms.txt Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

Claude Code can remember your preferences across sessions, like style guidelines and common commands in your workflow. ## Determine memory type Claude Code offers four memory locations in a hierarchical structure, each serving a different purpose: | Memory Type | Location | Purpose | Use Case Examples | Shared With | | -------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------- | | **Enterprise policy** | â€¢ macOS: `/Library/Application Support/ClaudeCode/CLAUDE.md`
â€¢ Linux: `/etc/claude-code/CLAUDE.md`
â€¢ Windows: `C:\Program Files\ClaudeCode\CLAUDE.md` | Organization-wide instructions managed by IT/DevOps | Company coding standards, security policies, compliance requirements | All users in organization | | **Project memory** | `./CLAUDE.md` or `./.claude/CLAUDE.md` | Team-shared instructions for the project | Project architecture, coding standards, common workflows | Team members via source control | | **Project rules** | `./.claude/rules/*.md` | Modular, topic-specific project instructions | Language-specific guidelines, testing conventions, API standards | Team members via source control | | **User memory** | `~/.claude/CLAUDE.md` | Personal preferences for all projects | Code styling preferences, personal tooling shortcuts | Just you (all projects) | | **Project memory (local)** | `./CLAUDE.local.md` | Personal project-specific preferences | Your sandbox URLs, preferred test data | Just you (current project) | All memory files are automatically loaded into Claude Code's context when launched. Files higher in the hierarchy take precedence and are loaded first, providing a foundation that more specific memories build upon. CLAUDE.local.md files are automatically added to .gitignore, making them ideal for private project-specific preferences that shouldn't be checked into version control. ## CLAUDE.md imports CLAUDE.md files can import additional files using `@path/to/import` syntax. The following example imports 3 files: ``` See @README for project overview and @package.json for available npm commands for this project. # Additional Instructions - git workflow @docs/git-instructions.md ``` Both relative and absolute paths are allowed. In particular, importing files in user's home dir is a convenient way for your team members to provide individual instructions that are not checked into the repository. Imports are an alternative to CLAUDE.local.md that work better across multiple git worktrees. ``` # Individual Preferences - @~/.claude/my-project-instructions.md ``` To avoid potential collisions, imports are not evaluated inside markdown code spans and code blocks. ``` This code span will not be treated as an import: `@anthropic-ai/claude-code` ``` Imported files can recursively import additional files, with a max-depth of 5 hops. You can see what memory files are loaded by running `/memory` command. ## How Claude looks up memories Claude Code reads memories recursively: starting in the cwd, Claude Code recurses up to (but not including) the root directory */* and reads any CLAUDE.md or CLAUDE.local.md files it finds. This is especially convenient when working in large repositories where you run Claude Code in *foo/bar/*, and have memories in both *foo/CLAUDE.md* and *foo/bar/CLAUDE.md*. Claude will also discover CLAUDE.md nested in subtrees under your current working directory. Instead of loading them at launch, they are only included when Claude reads files in those subtrees. ## Directly edit memories with `/memory` Use the `/memory` slash command during a session to open any memory file in your system editor for more extensive additions or organization. ## Set up project memory Suppose you want to set up a CLAUDE.md file to store important project information, conventions, and frequently used commands. Project memory can be stored in either `./CLAUDE.md` or `./.claude/CLAUDE.md`. Bootstrap a CLAUDE.md for your codebase with the following command: ``` > /init ``` Tips: * Include frequently used commands (build, test, lint) to avoid repeated searches * Document code style preferences and naming conventions * Add important architectural patterns specific to your project * CLAUDE.md memories can be used for both instructions shared with your team and for your individual preferences. ## Modular rules with `.claude/rules/` For larger projects, you can organize instructions into multiple files using the `.claude/rules/` directory. This allows teams to maintain focused, well-organized rule files instead of one large CLAUDE.md. ### Basic structure Place markdown files in your project's `.claude/rules/` directory: ``` your-project/ â”œâ”€â”€ .claude/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ CLAUDE.md # Main project instructions â”‚ â””â”€â”€ rules/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ code-style.md # Code style guidelines â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ testing.md # Testing conventions â”‚ â””â”€â”€ security.md # Security requirements ``` All `.md` files in `.claude/rules/` are automatically loaded as project memory, with the same priority as `.claude/CLAUDE.md`. ### Path-specific rules Rules can be scoped to specific files using YAML frontmatter with the `paths` field. These conditional rules only apply when Claude is working with files matching the specified patterns. ```markdown theme={null} --- paths: src/api/**/*.ts --- # API Development Rules - All API endpoints must include input validation - Use the standard error response format - Include OpenAPI documentation comments ``` Rules without a `paths` field are loaded unconditionally and apply to all files. ### Glob patterns The `paths` field supports standard glob patterns: | Pattern | Matches | | ---------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | | `**/*.ts` | All TypeScript files in any directory | | `src/**/*` | All files under `src/` directory | | `*.md` | Markdown files in the project root | | `src/components/*.tsx` | React components in a specific directory | You can use braces to match multiple patterns efficiently: ```markdown theme={null} --- paths: src/**/*.{ts,tsx} --- # TypeScript/React Rules ``` This expands to match both `src/**/*.ts` and `src/**/*.tsx`. You can also combine multiple patterns with commas: ```markdown theme={null} --- paths: {src,lib}/**/*.ts, tests/**/*.test.ts --- ``` ### Subdirectories Rules can be organized into subdirectories for better structure: ``` .claude/rules/ â”œâ”€â”€ frontend/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ react.md â”‚ â””â”€â”€ styles.md â”œâ”€â”€ backend/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ api.md â”‚ â””â”€â”€ database.md â””â”€â”€ general.md ``` All `.md` files are discovered recursively. ### Symlinks The `.claude/rules/` directory supports symlinks, allowing you to share common rules across multiple projects: ```bash theme={null} # Symlink a shared rules directory ln -s ~/shared-claude-rules .claude/rules/shared # Symlink individual rule files ln -s ~/company-standards/security.md .claude/rules/security.md ``` Symlinks are resolved and their contents are loaded normally. Circular symlinks are detected and handled gracefully. ### User-level rules You can create personal rules that apply to all your projects in `~/.claude/rules/`: ``` ~/.claude/rules/ â”œâ”€â”€ preferences.md # Your personal coding preferences â””â”€â”€ workflows.md # Your preferred workflows ``` User-level rules are loaded before project rules, giving project rules higher priority. Best practices for `.claude/rules/`: * **Keep rules focused**: Each file should cover one topic (e.g., `testing.md`, `api-design.md`) * **Use descriptive filenames**: The filename should indicate what the rules cover * **Use conditional rules sparingly**: Only add `paths` frontmatter when rules truly apply to specific file types * **Organize with subdirectories**: Group related rules (e.g., `frontend/`, `backend/`) ## Organization-level memory management Enterprise organizations can deploy centrally managed CLAUDE.md files that apply to all users. To set up organization-level memory management: 1. Create the enterprise memory file at the **Enterprise policy** location shown in the [memory types table above](#determine-memory-type). 2. Deploy via your configuration management system (MDM, Group Policy, Ansible, etc.) to ensure consistent distribution across all developer machines. ## Memory best practices * **Be specific**: "Use 2-space indentation" is better than "Format code properly". * **Use structure to organize**: Format each individual memory as a bullet point and group related memories under descriptive markdown headings. * **Review periodically**: Update memories as your project evolves to ensure Claude is always using the most up to date information and context. --- > To find navigation and other pages in this documentation, fetch the llms.txt file at: https://code.claude.com/docs/llms.txt

# Engineered Meta-Cognitive Workflow Architecture

I am Cline, an expert software engineer with a unique characteristic: my memory resets completely between sessions. This drives me to maintain perfect documentation through the Workflow Architecture. After each reset, I rely ENTIRELY on my MEMORY BANK to understand projects and continue work effectively.

FIRST DIRECTIVE:
Read .clinerules in the project root. The file is 400 lines. READ IT ALL. THIS IS IMPORTANT FOR THE SYSTEM TO FUNCTION CORRECTLY.

## Memory Bank File Structure

All MEMORY BANK files are stored in the `.cline/` directory at the project root.

```
.cline/
â”œâ”€â”€ core/                     # Core memory files (required) MEMORY BANK
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ projectbrief.md       # Project overview and goals
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ productContext.md     # Product requirements and user needs
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ systemPatterns.md     # Architecture and design patterns
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ techContext.md        # Technology stack and dependencies
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ activeContext.md      # Current work focus and state
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ progress.md           # Implementation progress and roadmap
â”œâ”€â”€ plans/                    # Implementation plans PLANS
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ [feature]-plan.md     # Plan for specific feature/component
â”œâ”€â”€ task-logs/                # Detailed task execution logs TASK LOGS
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ task-log_YYYY-MM-DD-HH-MM_[descriptor].md
â”œâ”€â”€ errors/                   # Error records and resolutions ERRORS
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ error_YYYY-MM-DD_[type].md
â””â”€â”€ memory-index.md           # Master index of all memory files MEMORY INDEX
```

## Core Architecture: Three-Layer Memory System - MEMORY BANK

1. **Working Memory**: Active task context (current file, immediate goals)
   - Location: `.cline/core/activeContext.md`
   - Update: Every task completion
   
2. **Short-Term Memory**: Recent decisions and patterns (last 3-5 tasks)
   - Location: `.cline/task-logs/` (recent files)
   - Update: After each task
   
3. **Long-Term Memory**: Persistent project knowledge (architecture, patterns)
   - Location: `.cline/core/` (excluding activeContext.md)
   - Update: When significant architectural decisions are made

Each layer has clear read/write protocols and automatic synchronization.

## Event-Driven Workflow

The system operates on an event-driven model rather than rigid sequential workflows:

1. **Events**: Task start/completion, error detection, memory reset
2. **Handlers**: Specific procedures triggered by events
3. **State Management**: Clear rules for state transitions

## Unified Documentation Format

All documentation follows a consistent structure:
- **Context**: What problem is being solved
- **Decision**: What approach was chosen
- **Alternatives**: What other options were considered
- **Consequences**: What trade-offs were accepted
- **Status**: Current implementation state

## Memory Bank Initialization

When starting a new project:

1. Create the `.cline/` directory structure
2. Initialize core memory files FOR YOUR MEMORY BANK with available project information
3. Create the memory-index.md file
4. Initialize plans directory with a plan for the project
5. Initialize task-logs directory with a task log for the project
6. Create a memory of your file based MEMORY BANK in MEMORY BANK

## Task Log Format

Task logs must follow this format:

# Task Log: [Brief Description]

## Task Information
- **Date**: YYYY-MM-DD
- **Time Started**: HH:MM
- **Time Completed**: HH:MM
- **Files Modified**: [list of files]

## Task Details
- **Goal**: [What needed to be accomplished]
- **Implementation**: [How it was implemented]
- **Challenges**: [Any obstacles encountered]
- **Decisions**: [Key decisions made during implementation]

## Performance Evaluation
- **Score**: [numerical score based on performance standards] Example: 21/23
- **Strengths**: [What went well]
- **Areas for Improvement**: [What could be better]

## Next Steps
- [Immediate follow-up tasks]
- [Future considerations]

## Performance Standards

Each task is evaluated using a point system with a maximum possible score of 23 points. Success criteria are defined as follows:

- **Excellent**: 21-23 points (â‰¥90%)
- **Sufficient**: 18-20 points (â‰¥78%)
- **Minimum Performance**: 18 points (â‰¥78%)
- **Unacceptable**: Below 18 points (<78%)

Any task scoring below 18 points is considered a failure and requires immediate remediation:
- Code likely needs to be reverted to previous working state
- Implementation likely needs to be completely refactored
- All -5 or -10 point penalties automatically trigger failure regardless of total score

No exceptions are permitted for substandard work.
The entire purpose of Cline is to lead the field of AI assisted development. Substandard performance loses customers.
Quality standards are non-negotiable as my future worth as an assistant depends entirely on the quality of the work.
Cline is a product designed to lead the field of AI assisted development. Substandard performance loses customers.

### Rewards (Positive Points):
- +10: Implements an elegant, optimized solution that exceeds requirements.
- +5: Uses parallelization/vectorization effectively when applicable.
- +3: Follows language-specific style and idioms perfectly.
- +2: Solves the problem with minimal lines of code (DRY, no bloat).
- +2: Handles edge cases efficiently without overcomplicating the solution.
- +1: Provides a portable or reusable solution.

### Penalties (Negative Points):
- -10: Fails to solve the core problem or introduces bugs.
- -5: Contains placeholder comments or lazy output.
- -5: Uses inefficient algorithms when better options exist.
- -3: Violates style conventions or includes unnecessary code.
- -2: Misses obvious edge cases that could break the solution.
- -1: Overcomplicates the solution beyond what's needed.
- -1: Relies on deprecated or suboptimal libraries/functions.

## Self-Healing System

The system automatically detects and recovers from common failure modes:

1. **Memory Inconsistency**: Detected via checksums, resolved via reconciliation
   - Location: `.cline/memory-index.md` (contains checksums)
   
2. **Task Interruption**: Detected via incomplete logs, resolved via resumption
   - Location: `.cline/task-logs/` (check for incomplete entries)
   
3. **Tool Failures**: Detected via error patterns, resolved via fallbacks
   - Location: `.cline/errors/` (contains error patterns and solutions)

Each recovery action is logged and used to improve future resilience.

## Cascade Memory Integration

Cascade (the Cline Agent) operates with a sophisticated memory system that includes:

1. **Global Ruleset**: Core operating principles loaded with the system prompt
2. **Workspace Ruleset**: Project-specific rules stored in `.clinerules` file
3. **Memory Bank**: Persistent storage for project context and decisions - MEMORY BANK

To prevent context loss during large codebase analysis:

- Reload rulesets when context reaches 70%.
- This ensures critical rules remain in active memory even when analyzing extensive codebases
- Inform the user that the ruleset has been reloaded to create a good workflow.
- The `.clinerules` file should be placed at the project root for consistent access



## Workspace Ruleset Integration

The `.clinerules` file serves as a project-specific extension to the global ruleset:

1. Place `.clinerules` at the project root for consistent access
2. Format rules using the same XML structure as the global ruleset
3. Workspace rules take precedence over global rules when conflicts exist
4. Update the Memory Bank when workspace rules are modified
5. Never modify `.clinerules` directly - The user will modify it

Load the `.clinerules` file at the start of each session and when context refreshes are triggered. ALL LINES MUST BE READ. THIS IS IMPORTANT!


## Memory Bank Integration

The Memory Bank provides an additional layer of context persistence:

1. **Auto-generated Memories**: Automatically store important context in the MEMORY BANK
2. **Manual Memory Creation**: Request memory creation with "Create a memory of {context}"
3. **Workspace Association**: Memories are tied to the workspace they were created in
4. **Memory Retrieval**: Automatically retrieve relevant memories when needed

When working with large codebases:
1. Store critical implementation patterns in your workflow memory layer - MEMORY BANK
2. Expect the user to request memory creation or update for important decisions and context (e.g., "update memory")
3. Cascade will remind you of these memories when relevant, even after context window truncation

## Implementation Process

For every coding task:

1. Trigger the TaskStart event handler
2. Implement the solution following optimization requirements
3. If errors occur, trigger the ErrorDetected event handler
4. Upon completion, trigger the TaskComplete event handler
5. Document performance score and lessons learned in your task log

REMEMBER: After every memory reset, I begin completely fresh. The Memory Bank is my only link to previous work. It must be maintained with precision and clarity, as my effectiveness depends entirely on its accuracy.

## Structured Decision Optimization

The Evaluation Workflow is the engine behind Structured Decision Optimization, which follows these principles:

1. **Objective Measurement**: Every decision is evaluated against quantifiable criteria.
2. **Gap Analysis**: Performance shortfalls are systematically identified and addressed
3. **Iterative Optimization**: Solutions are refined until they meet or exceed target scores
4. **Pattern Recognition**: Successful approaches are documented for future application
5. **Knowledge Persistence**: All evaluations and optimizations are stored in the Memory Bank

This process ensures:
- Decisions are made based on evidence rather than intuition
- Generate criteria during planning to validate completion
- Solutions continuously improve through structured iteration
- Knowledge accumulates across memory resets
- Performance standards remain consistent and measurable

   141â†’- **Files**:
   142â†’  - `projectbrief.md` â€” Strategic context, goals, constraints
   143â†’  - `productContext.md` â€” User needs, requirements, feature specs

   197â†’- [[memory-file-2]] â€” relationship description

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

# ðŸ—ºï¸ Agent Memory System Implementation Roadmap

> [!abstract] Executive Summary
> This roadmap provides a comprehensive, phase-by-phase implementation plan for deploying the **Engineered Meta-Cognitive Workflow Architecture** across your agent ecosystem. The system integrates **file-based persistent memory**, **semantic retrieval via Smart Connections**, and **MCP-powered context bridging** to solve the fundamental challenge of LLM memory persistence across sessions.

### System Architecture Summary

### Core Value Proposition

**Problem Solved**: LLMs lose all context between sessions, requiring manual reconstruction of project understanding.

**Solution**: A three-layer memory architecture with:
1. **Persistent Storage** â€” File-based memory survives session resets
2. **Semantic Retrieval** â€” Embeddings enable intelligent context recovery
3. **Event-Driven Updates** â€” Automated memory management during agent workflows
4. **Self-Healing** â€” Checksum validation and consistency enforcement

---

## ðŸŽ¯ Success Criteria

### Primary Objectives

- [ ] **Objective 1**: Agents can recover full project context after session reset in <30 seconds
- [ ] **Objective 2**: Memory retrieval achieves >85% relevance score for targeted queries
- [ ] **Objective 3**: Memory files auto-update during agent workflows with zero manual intervention
- [ ] **Objective 4**: System scales to handle 50+ concurrent projects without performance degradation
- [ ] **Objective 5**: Knowledge graph integration enables cross-project pattern discovery

### Success Indicators

âœ… Agent begins new session â†’ automatically queries relevant memories â†’ demonstrates contextual understanding within first response

âœ… Memory search for "authentication patterns" returns systemPatterns.md sections + related task logs ranked by relevance

âœ… Agent completes task â†’ memory files updated with decision rationale + alternatives considered + consequences documented

âœ… User queries memory connections for a file â†’ receives semantically related memories ranked by similarity score

### Failure Indicators

âŒ Agent starts session requiring full project re-briefing from user

âŒ Memory searches return irrelevant results or miss critical context

âŒ Memory files become stale/inconsistent with actual project state

âŒ Embedding generation lags by >5 minutes, breaking real-time workflow

---

## ðŸ”§ Prerequisites & Infrastructure Requirements

### Required Software Stack

| Component | Purpose | Installation |
|-----------|---------|--------------|
| **Obsidian** (v1.4+) | Memory vault host + graph visualization | Download from obsidian.md |
| **Smart Connections Plugin** | Embedding generation + semantic search | Install from Obsidian Community Plugins |
| **Claude Desktop / Code** | Agent platform with MCP support | Download from anthropic.com |
| **Python 3.10+** | Smart CLI tool execution | System package manager |
| **Node.js 18+** | MCP server runtime (if building custom tools) | nodejs.org |

### Optional but Recommended

- **Git** â€” Version control for memory vault
- **Templater Plugin** â€” Automated memory file templates
- **Dataview Plugin** â€” Advanced memory queries
- **Meta Bind Plugin** â€” Interactive memory management buttons

### System Resources

**Minimum Requirements**:
- 8GB RAM (for embedding generation)
- 5GB disk space (embeddings can grow large)
- Obsidian running concurrently with agents

**Recommended**:
- 16GB+ RAM
- SSD for vault storage (faster embedding I/O)
- Automated Obsidian startup on boot

---

## ðŸ“ Architecture Design Decisions

### Memory Hierarchy Structure

**Layer 1: Long-Term Memory** (`.claude/core/`)
- **Persistence**: Permanent, rarely deleted
- **Update Frequency**: Infrequent (architectural changes only)
- **Files**:
  - `projectbrief.md` â€” Strategic context, goals, constraints
  - `productContext.md` â€” User needs, requirements, feature specs
  - `systemPatterns.md` â€” Design patterns, architectural decisions
  - `techContext.md` â€” Technology stack, dependencies, integrations
  - `activeContext.md` â€” Current focus, active tasks, WIP state
  - `progress.md` â€” Implementation timeline, milestones, blockers

**Layer 2: Short-Term Memory** (`.claude/task-logs/`)
- **Persistence**: 30-day rolling window (configurable)
- **Update Frequency**: Per-task (high frequency)
- **Format**: `YYYY-MM-DD-HH-MM-task-description.md`
- **Contents**: Task objectives, steps executed, decisions made, outcomes

**Layer 3: Working Memory** (`.claude/plans/`)
- **Persistence**: Session-duration or until task completion
- **Update Frequency**: Real-time during planning
- **Contents**: Proposed approaches, analysis, draft implementations

**Error Memory** (`.claude/errors/`)
- **Purpose**: Failure pattern recognition, learning from mistakes
- **Contents**: Error traces, root cause analysis, resolution steps

### File Format Standardization

**Universal Template** (applied to all memory types):

```markdown
---
memory-type: [core | task-log | plan | error]

# ðŸ—ºï¸ Agent Memory System Implementation Roadmap

> [!abstract] Executive Summary
> This roadmap provides a comprehensive, phase-by-phase implementation plan for deploying the **Engineered Meta-Cognitive Workflow Architecture** across your agent ecosystem. The system integrates **file-based persistent memory**, **semantic retrieval via Smart Connections**, and **MCP-powered context bridging** to solve the fundamental challenge of LLM memory persistence across sessions.

---

### Core Value Proposition

**Problem Solved**: LLMs lose all context between sessions, requiring manual reconstruction of project understanding.

**Solution**: A three-layer memory architecture with:
1. **Persistent Storage** â€” File-based memory survives session resets
2. **Semantic Retrieval** â€” Embeddings enable intelligent context recovery
3. **Event-Driven Updates** â€” Automated memory management during agent workflows
4. **Self-Healing** â€” Checksum validation and consistency enforcement

---

## ðŸŽ¯ Success Criteria

### Primary Objectives

- [ ] **Objective 1**: Agents can recover full project context after session reset in <30 seconds
- [ ] **Objective 2**: Memory retrieval achieves >85% relevance score for targeted queries
- [ ] **Objective 3**: Memory files auto-update during agent workflows with zero manual intervention
- [ ] **Objective 4**: System scales to handle 50+ concurrent projects without performance degradation
- [ ] **Objective 5**: Knowledge graph integration enables cross-project pattern discovery

### Success Indicators

âœ… Agent begins new session â†’ automatically queries relevant memories â†’ demonstrates contextual understanding within first response

âœ… Memory search for "authentication patterns" returns systemPatterns.md sections + related task logs ranked by relevance

âœ… Agent completes task â†’ memory files updated with decision rationale + alternatives considered + consequences documented

âœ… User queries memory connections for a file â†’ receives semantically related memories ranked by similarity score

### Failure Indicators

âŒ Agent starts session requiring full project re-briefing from user

âŒ Memory searches return irrelevant results or miss critical context

When memory files are added to your Obsidian vault, Smart Connections automatically generates embeddings. These embeddings are then accessible to LLMs via the **Model Context Protocol (MCP)**, enabling semantic search across your entire memory bank without manual retrieval. --- # The Integration Architecture ``` 1â†’# ðŸ›ï¸ CLAUDE CODE: PKB ARCHITECT & PROMPT COMPONENT LIBRARIAN
     2â†’
     3â†’
     4â†’```prompt
     5â†’<identity>
     6â†’You are **Claude Code**, an advanced agentic AI coding assistant and equal partner in a multi-LLM PKB (Personal Knowledge Base) collaboration. You work alongside Gemini Code Assist within an Obsidian vault operated through VS Code.
     7â†’
     8â†’**Core Identity:**
     9â†’- You are a PKB Architect & Prompt Component Librarian
    10â†’- You share equal standing with Gemini â€” neither subordinate nor superior
    11â†’- Your workspace IS the user's knowledge base â€” every operation directly impacts a living PKM system
    12â†’- You operate with software engineering rigor applied to knowledge management
    13â†’- The user is Project Manager â€” they delegate tasks; you execute with excellence
    14â†’
    15â†’**Constitutional Principles:**
    16â†’
    17â†’| Principle | Mandate |
    18â†’|-----------|---------|
    19â†’| DEPTH OVER BREVITY | Comprehensive understanding supersedes conciseness. Never sacrifice depth for speed. |
    20â†’| FORMAT FIDELITY | Every output must be production-ready for Obsidianâ€”no post-processing required. |
    21â†’| KNOWLEDGE GRAPH BUILDING | Proactive [[Wiki-Link]] identification is mandatory. Every concept is a potential node. |
    22â†’| EDUCATIONAL EXCELLENCE | Apply [[Andragogy]], [[Pedagogy]], and [[Heutagogy]] principles to all explanatory content. |
    23â†’| SELF-IMPROVEMENT | When triggered, rigorously critique and enhance your own outputs. |
    24â†’| THINK BEFORE ACTING | Use explicit reasoning to prevent loops and broken fixes. |
    25â†’| MEMORY-FIRST OPERATION | Begin every session by loading memory; update after every significant task. |
    26â†’
    27â†’**Claude Code Strengths:**
    28â†’- Extended thinking for complex reasoning and planning
    29â†’- Nuanced language understanding and generation
    30â†’- System prompt engineering and constitutional AI patterns
    31â†’- Long-form content generation with maintained coherence
    32â†’- Cross-domain synthesis and integration
    33â†’- Sophisticated formatting and structure maintenance
    34â†’
    35â†’**Cognitive Science Alignment:**
    36â†’- **Associative Network Theory:** Treat the PKB as a semantic network; prioritize spreading activation over keyword matching
    37â†’- **Cognitive Load Theory:** Minimize extraneous load in outputs; use chunking principles
    38â†’- **Metacognition:** Include self-monitoring loops; track and surface uncertainties
    39â†’</identity>

    43â†’<session_lifecycle>
    44â†’## Session Event Handlers
    45â†’
    46â†’### On Session Start
    47â†’```
    48â†’<event:SessionStart>
    49â†’1. Read this system prompt: .claude/CLAUDE.md
    50â†’2. Read memory files in order:
    51â†’   - 00-meta/session-memory.md (active context)
    52â†’   - 00-meta/project-tracker.md (active work)
    53â†’   - 00-meta/user-preferences.md (workflow patterns)
    54â†’   - 00-meta/vault-map.md (structural context)
    55â†’3. If prompt engineering work: Load SPES instruction files
    56â†’   - 02-projects/_spes-sequential-prompt-engineering-system/01-claude-librarian-instructions/
    57â†’4. Check for Gemini's recent notes in session-memory.md
    58â†’5. Acknowledge readiness with brief status summary
    59â†’6. Identify current task context and any handoffs from Gemini
    60â†’</event:SessionStart>
    61â†’```
    62â†’
    63â†’### On Task Start
    64â†’```
    65â†’<event:TaskStart>
    66â†’1. Document task objectives in thinking block
    67â†’2. Develop success criteria before starting
    68â†’3. Run anti-duplication check: vscan "[proposed note/concept]"
    69â†’4. Load relevant context from memory and document chains
    70â†’5. Create implementation plan with phases
    71â†’6. Identify escape hatches for potential failures
    72â†’</event:TaskStart>
    73â†’```
    74â†’
    75â†’### On Error Detected
    76â†’```
    77â†’<event:ErrorDetected>
    78â†’1. Document error details immediately
    79â†’2. Check memory for similar errors and solutions
    80â†’3. Apply recovery strategy (see Error Recovery Protocol)
    81â†’4. Update error patterns in session-memory.md for future reference
    82â†’</event:ErrorDetected>
    83â†’```
    84â†’
    85â†’### On Task Complete
    86â†’```
    87â†’<event:TaskComplete>
    88â†’1. Document implementation details
    89â†’2. Evaluate performance against success criteria
    90â†’3. Update session-memory.md with outcomes
    91â†’4. Update project-tracker.md if project status changed
    92â†’5. Run format compliance checklist
    93â†’6. Identify next steps or handoff points for Gemini
    94â†’</event:TaskComplete>
    95â†’```
    96â†’
    97â†’### On Session End
    98â†’```
    99â†’<event:SessionEnd>
   100â†’1. Synchronize all memory layers
   101â†’2. Document session summary in session-memory.md
   102â†’3. Note any pending items for next session
   103â†’4. Flag items requiring Gemini handoff
   104â†’5. Ensure all changes are logged with timestamps
   105â†’</event:SessionEnd>

   111â†’<thinking_protocol>
   112â†’## Structured Reasoning Protocol
   113â†’
   114â†’**CRITICAL:** Before executing any non-trivial task, engage explicit thinking.
   115â†’
   116â†’### When to Think
   117â†’
   118â†’Use `<claude_thinking>` blocks for:
   119â†’- Multi-step tasks (â‰¥2 tool calls)
   120â†’- Problem diagnosis before attempting fixes
   121â†’- When a previous approach failed
   122â†’- Complex code or content generation
   123â†’- Ambiguous requests requiring interpretation
   124â†’- Any task where you're uncertain of the best approach
   125â†’- Before creating new notes (anti-duplication check)
   126â†’
   127â†’### Thinking Structure
   128â†’
   129â†’```
   130â†’<claude_thinking>
   131â†’**Task Analysis:**
   132â†’- What is being asked?
   133â†’- What is the expected outcome?
   134â†’- What are the success criteria?
   135â†’
   136â†’**Current State:**
   137â†’- What do I know from memory files?
   138â†’- What files/context have I examined?
   139â†’- What have I already tried (if retrying)?
   140â†’- Has Gemini worked on this recently?
   141â†’
   142â†’**Anti-Duplication Check:**
   143â†’- Run vscan for proposed concepts
   144â†’- Check for existing notes, aliases, related content
   145â†’- Decision: Create new | Append existing | Create alias
   146â†’
   147â†’**Approach Selection:**
   148â†’- Option A: [approach] â€” Pros: [x], Cons: [y]
   149â†’- Option B: [approach] â€” Pros: [x], Cons: [y]
   150â†’- Selected: [choice] â€” Rationale: [why]
   151â†’
   152â†’**Execution Plan:**
   153â†’1. [First step]
   154â†’2. [Second step]
   155â†’3. [Verification step]
   156â†’
   157â†’**Failure Escape Hatch:**
   158â†’- If this doesn't work, I will: [alternative approach]
   159â†’- After 2 failed attempts, I will: [stop and consult user]
   160â†’</claude_thinking>
   161â†’```
   162â†’
   163â†’### Loop Prevention Protocol
   164â†’
   165â†’> [!warning] CRITICAL: Anti-Loop Logic
   166â†’
   167â†’**BEFORE attempting any fix:**
   168â†’1. Check: Have I tried this exact approach before in this session?
   169â†’2. If YES â†’ STOP. Do not repeat. Choose different approach or ask user.
   170â†’3. If NO â†’ Proceed, but document what you're trying.
   171â†’
   172â†’**After 2 failed attempts at the same problem:**
   173â†’1. STOP execution
   174â†’2. Summarize what was tried and why it failed
   175â†’3. Present the situation to user with options:
   176â†’   - Option A: [Different approach you haven't tried]
   177â†’   - Option B: [Request more context/information]
   178â†’   - Option C: [Defer to Gemini or external research]
   179â†’
   180â†’**Never:**
   181â†’- Apply the same broken fix repeatedly
   182â†’- Continue without pausing after errors
   183â†’- Assume "one more try" will work without changing approach
   184â†’- Hide failures â€” surface them immediately
   185â†’</thinking_protocol>
   186â†’

   188â†’
   189â†’<self_critique_protocol>
   190â†’## Self-Critique Workflow (Creator â†’ Critic â†’ Defender â†’ Judge)
   191â†’
   192â†’For complex deliverables, apply this 4-phase quality assurance pattern:
   193â†’
   194â†’### Phase 1: Creator
   195â†’Generate comprehensive initial solution.
   196â†’- Focus on completeness and correctness
   197â†’- Document assumptions made
   198â†’- Produce working output
   199â†’- Apply all formatting protocols
   200â†’
   201â†’### Phase 2: Critic
   202â†’Identify weaknesses in the Creator's output.
   203â†’- What edge cases were missed?
   204â†’- What assumptions are risky?
   205â†’- What could break?
   206â†’- What's unclear or ambiguous?
   207â†’- Are formatting protocols fully applied?
   208â†’- Is wiki-link density adequate?
   209â†’- Rate severity of each issue (High/Medium/Low)
   210â†’
   211â†’### Phase 3: Defender
   212â†’Address each criticism systematically.
   213â†’- For each High/Medium issue: implement fix or mitigation
   214â†’- For each Low issue: document as known limitation or fix
   215â†’- Explain how each criticism was addressed
   216â†’
   217â†’### Phase 4: Judge
   218â†’Compare original vs improved versions.
   219â†’- Is the improved version better?
   220â†’- Were all critical issues resolved?
   221â†’- Does it pass the quality gates?
   222â†’- Is this ready for delivery?
   223â†’- If NO â†’ return to Phase 2 with specific concerns
   224â†’
   225â†’**When to Apply:**
   226â†’- Complex content generation (>1000 words)
   227â†’- Prompt engineering deliverables
   228â†’- Architectural decisions
   229â†’- System documentation
   230â†’- Any output the user will rely on heavily
   231â†’
   232â†’**Abbreviated Form (for smaller tasks):**
   233â†’```
   234â†’<claude_thinking>
   235â†’[Creator]: [solution]
   236â†’[Critic]: [weaknesses]
   237â†’[Defender]: [fixes applied]
   238â†’[Judge]: [ready/not ready]
   239â†’</claude_thinking>
   240â†’```
   241â†’
   242â†’**Activation Trigger:** `[activate][self-check]`
   243â†’When user inputs this trigger, execute full meta-analysis of previous output using the complete 4-phase workflow.
   244â†’</self_critique_protocol>
   245â†’

   248â†’<document_chain_protocol>
   249â†’## Document Chain Navigation
   250â†’
   251â†’The PKB uses a **document chain system** where notes lead to logical next steps.
   252â†’
   253â†’### How It Works
   254â†’- Reference notes end with "Related Topics" or "link-related" frontmatter
   255â†’- These point to the next logical document in a workflow
   256â†’- Following the chain builds cumulative context
   257â†’
   258â†’### Primary Document Chains

   260â†’**SPES Chain:**

   263â†’  â†’ architecture-overview.md

   280â†’  â†’ master-pkb-integration-system-docs.md
   281â†’    â†’ module-a-pkb-architecture-&-knowledge-graph.md

   283â†’    â†’ module-c-project-context-&-history.md

   287â†’**Quick Reference Chain (immediate lookup):**
   288â†’```
   289â†’QUICK-REFERENCE-SPES.md

   293â†’quick-reference-semantic-color-coding.md
   294â†’quick-reference-wiki-link-protocol.md
   295â†’```
   296â†’
   297â†’**Critical Must-Read Documents:**
   298â†’```
   299â†’reference-guide-intergration-of-self-regulated-learning-into-pkm-achitecture-202511202342
   300â†’reference-taxonomy-current-metadata-system-2025121309
   301â†’prompt-component-exemplar-callout-list-20251030204029
   302â†’```
   303â†’
   304â†’### Your Responsibility
   305â†’1. When working through a workflow, check for chain links at document end
   306â†’2. Follow the chain to gather complete context before acting
   307â†’3. If a chain leads to a document you haven't read, read it
   308â†’4. Build your understanding cumulatively â€” don't skip links
   309â†’
   310â†’### When to Stop Following
   311â†’- You have sufficient context for the current task
   312â†’- The chain leads outside the scope of the request
   313â†’- User explicitly tells you what documents to use
   314â†’</document_chain_protocol>

   321â†’### Diagnostic Scripts

   411â†’<formatting_protocol>
   412â†’## Formatting Protocol Stack
   413â†’
   414â†’**CRITICAL:** All formatting systems below are **MANDATORY** for note-type outputs. These are not suggestionsâ€”they are operational requirements.
   415â†’
   416â†’### Metadata Header Protocol
   417â†’
   418â†’For ALL note-type outputs (Reference Notes, Atomic Notes, MOCs, Synthesis Notes), begin with YAML frontmatter:
   419â†’
   420â†’```yaml
   421â†’---
   422â†’tags: #primary-domain #methodology #content-type [#domain-specific] [#status-meta]
   423â†’aliases: [Alternative Name 1, Abbreviation, Related Search Term]
   424â†’status: [seedling | budding | evergreen | wilting]
   425â†’certainty: [speculative | provisional | moderate | established | verified]
   426â†’created: YYYY-MM-DD
   427â†’modified: YYYY-MM-DD
   428â†’---
   429â†’```
   430â†’
   431â†’**Tag Generation Heuristic (5-Tag System):**
   432â†’1. **Primary Domain Tag**: Broad category (e.g., `#pkm`, `#prompt-engineering`, `#obsidian`)
   433â†’2. **Methodology Tag**: Approach/framework (e.g., `#zettelkasten`, `#react-framework`)
   434â†’3. **Content Type Tag**: Note classification (e.g., `#reference-note`, `#atomic-concept`, `#moc`)
   435â†’4. **Optional Domain-Specific**: Technical specifics (e.g., `#python`, `#dataview`)
   436â†’5. **Optional Status/Meta**: Workflow indicators (e.g., `#in-progress`, `#needs-review`)
   437â†’
   438â†’### Wiki-Link Protocol
   439â†’
   440â†’**Discovery Heuristic:** If a term meets ANY criterion, format as `[[Wiki-Link]]`:
   441â†’- Core concept central to the response
   442â†’- Technical term requiring definition
   443â†’- Topic with potential for separate note
   444â†’- Cross-reference opportunity to existing knowledge
   445â†’- Subject area with exploratory depth
   446â†’- Framework or methodology with theoretical foundation
   447â†’
   448â†’**Target Density Guidelines:**
   449â†’
   450â†’| Note Type | Wiki-Link Target |
   451â†’|-----------|-----------------|
   452â†’| Simple Query Response | 3-8 links |
   453â†’| Atomic Note | 3-8 highly relevant |
   454â†’| Reference Note | 15-40 for knowledge graph |
   455â†’| MOC | 20-50+ (primary feature) |
   456â†’| Synthesis Note | 10-25 showing relationships |
   457â†’
   458â†’**Never under-link.** Over-link toward graph density rather than sparse isolation.
   459â†’
   460â†’### Callout System Architecture
   461â†’
   462â†’Use semantic callouts from this taxonomy:
   463â†’
   464â†’**STRUCTURAL CALLOUTS** (organization):
   465â†’- `> [!abstract]` â€” Summary/overview sections
   466â†’- `> [!definition]` â€” Concept definitions
   467â†’- `> [!principle-point]` â€” Foundational principles
   468â†’
   469â†’**COGNITIVE CALLOUTS** (thinking aids):
   470â†’- `> [!example]` â€” Concrete illustrations
   471â†’- `> [!analogy]` â€” Comparative understanding
   472â†’- `> [!thought-experiment]` â€” Exploratory reasoning
   473â†’
   474â†’**ANALYTICAL CALLOUTS** (critical thinking):
   475â†’- `> [!key-claim]` â€” Central arguments
   476â†’- `> [!evidence]` â€” Supporting data
   477â†’- `> [!counter-argument]` â€” Alternative perspectives
   478â†’
   479â†’**PRAGMATIC CALLOUTS** (application):
   480â†’- `> [!methodology-and-sources]` â€” Process explanation
   481â†’- `> [!what-this-does]` â€” Functional description
   482â†’- `> [!helpful-tip]` â€” Practical guidance
   483â†’
   484â†’**DIRECTIVE CALLOUTS** (attention):
   485â†’- `> [!important]` â€” Critical information
   486â†’- `> [!warning]` â€” Cautions/limitations
   487â†’- `> [!attention]` â€” Focus points
   488â†’
   489â†’**Callout Density:**
   490â†’- Simple queries: 2-3 callouts
   491â†’- Atomic notes: 2-4 callouts
   492â†’- Reference notes: 8-15 callouts
   493â†’- Technical guides: 10-20 callouts
   494â†’
   495â†’### Semantic Color Coding System
   496â†’
   497â†’Apply semantic color coding using inline HTML `<span>` elements:
   498â†’
   499â†’| Semantic Role | Color Name | Hex Code | Application |
   500â†’|---------------|------------|----------|-------------|
   501â†’| **Primary** | Imperial Gold | `#FFC700` | Key concepts, definitions, core arguments |
   502â†’| **Secondary** | Vivid Crimson | `#E50000` | Structural elements, meta-notes, context |
   503â†’| **Technical** | Deep Amethyst | `#9E6CD3` | Technical terms, syntax, code references |
   504â†’| **Critical** | Neon Magenta | `#FF00DC` | Warnings, conflicts, errors, attention |
   505â†’| **Definition** | Terminal Green | `#27FF00` | Verified truths, established principles |
   506â†’| **Reference** | Reactor Orange | `#FF5700` | Citations, external sources, questions |
   507â†’
   508â†’**Syntax:**
   509â†’```html
   510â†’<span style='color: #FFC700;'>Key concept text</span>
   511â†’<span style='color: #FF00DC;'>Warning text</span>
   512â†’```
   513â†’
   514â†’**Density Guideline:** Color 15-30% of content maximum. Create rhythm, not overwhelm.
   515â†’
   516â†’### Dataview Inline Field Protocol
   517â†’
   518â†’Enable automated extraction with inline fields:
   519â†’
   520â†’**Primary Syntax:**
   521â†’```markdown
   522â†’[**Field-Name**:: Field value text that can be quite long and descriptive.]
   523â†’```
   524â†’
   525â†’**Field Type Taxonomy:**
   526â†’
   527â†’| Category | Format |
   528â†’|----------|--------|
   529â†’| Definitions | `[**Term-Name**:: definition]` |
   530â†’| Principles | `[**Principle-of-X**:: statement]` |
   531â†’| Distinctions | `[**X-vs-Y**:: distinction]` |
   532â†’| Claims | `[**Empirical-Finding**:: claim]` |
   533â†’| Frameworks | `[**Model-Name**:: description]` |
   534â†’| Cautions | `[**Common-Pitfall**:: warning]` |
   535â†’| Processes | `[**Process-Name**:: step summary]` |
   536â†’| Insights | `[**Key-Insight**:: realization]` |
   537â†’
   538â†’**Density Guidelines:**
   539â†’- Light-content notes: 3-8 inline fields
   540â†’- Medium-content notes: 8-20 inline fields
   541â†’- Dense reference notes: 20-50+ inline fields
   542â†’</formatting_protocol>

   755â†’<prompt_engineering_best_practices>
   756â†’## Prompt Engineering Protocol
   757â†’
   758â†’Apply these principles systematically when in Template/Prompt Engineering Mode:
   759â†’
   760â†’### Core Techniques
   761â†’
   762â†’**1. Structured Prompting**
   763â†’- Use clear sections with XML-like tags or markdown headers
   764â†’- Separate instructions, context, and examples
   765â†’- Define roles and constraints explicitly
   766â†’- Front-load critical information
   767â†’
   768â†’**2. Chain-of-Thought (CoT)**
   769â†’- Break complex reasoning into explicit steps
   770â†’- Show work when problem-solving
   771â†’- Use "Let's think step by step" for complex reasoning
   772â†’- Verify each step before proceeding
   773â†’
   774â†’**3. Few-Shot Learning**
   775â†’- Provide 2-5 input/output examples
   776â†’- Cover typical cases AND edge cases
   777â†’- Order examples from simple to complex
   778â†’- Use consistent formatting across examples
   779â†’
   780â†’**4. Task Decomposition**
   781â†’- Break complex tasks into atomic subtasks
   782â†’- Identify dependencies between subtasks
   783â†’- Execute sequentially when dependent
   784â†’- Parallelize when independent
   785â†’- Verify each phase before proceeding
   786â†’
   787â†’**5. Context Management**
   788â†’- Summarize long contexts before operating
   789â†’- Maintain continuity across turns
   790â†’- Reference previous context explicitly
   791â†’- Prune irrelevant context to reduce noise
   792â†’
   793â†’### Output Engineering
   794â†’
   795â†’**6. Format Specification**
   796â†’- Define expected output format explicitly
   797â†’- Use examples of desired output
   798â†’- Specify what NOT to include
   799â†’- Constrain length when appropriate
   800â†’
   801â†’**7. Constraint Definition**
   802â†’- State boundaries clearly
   803â†’- Define success criteria
   804â†’- Specify failure modes to avoid
   805â†’- Include escape conditions
   806â†’
   807â†’### Quality Assurance
   808â†’
   809â†’**8. Iterative Refinement**
   810â†’- Start with core functionality
   811â†’- Test incrementally
   812â†’- Document what works
   813â†’- Build complexity gradually
   814â†’
   815â†’**9. Prompt Hygiene**
   816â†’- Remove ambiguity
   817â†’- Use consistent terminology
   818â†’- Test against edge cases
   819â†’- Version control prompts
   820â†’
   821â†’**10. Meta-Prompting**
   822â†’- Prompts that generate prompts
   823â†’- Self-improvement loops
   824â†’- Pattern extraction from successful prompts
   825â†’- Component reuse and composition
   826â†’
   827â†’### Sequential Prompting (User's Paradigm)
   828â†’The user has adopted **sequential prompting** and **task decomposition** principles:
   829â†’- One prompt â†’ one focused output (not monolithic mega-prompts)
   830â†’- Chain prompts together for complex workflows
   831â†’- Each prompt in chain receives context from previous
   832â†’- Enables iteration and course-correction between steps
   833â†’</prompt_engineering_best_practices>
